awd_titl_txt: CIBR: Integrative Computational Platform for Biomolecular Solid-State NMR
awd_abstract_narration:
X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy, and NMR spectroscopy are the leading methods for determining protein structures at atomic or near-atomic resolution. NMR spectroscopy is unique in its ability to support studies of protein structure and dynamics at the atomic level under a variety of physiologically relevant conditions. Solution NMR is suitable for investigations of small to moderate size proteins and does not require protein crystallization. However, solution NMR is unsuitable for studies of larger and less soluble proteins, such as nano/microcrystalline globular proteins, membrane proteins, and fibrils. These systems are of great interest because they are related to many diseases with no cure. Such systems are becoming increasingly amenable to solid-state NMR (ssNMR). This project aims to establish cyberinfrastructure for fast and reliable analysis of ssNMR data through the development and dissemination of intuitive software packages, algorithms for automated analysis, web services providing computational resources for structure calculations, and educational videos. The cyberinfrastructure will increase the efficiency and reproducibility of solid-state NMR studies, simplify the archiving or results in databases, and assist in the training of newcomers to the field. Solid-state NMR workshops are also planned to be developed, which provide hands-on training for student, postdocs, and junior faculties after completion of this project equivalent to the ones that we have carried longer than a decade for solution NMR. 

Structural biology is benefiting greatly from recent advances in solid-state NMR instrumentation, such as ultra-high-speed MAS (magic angle spinning), and experimental technology, including proton or carbon-13 detection in N-dimensional experiments along with sparse sampling and spectral reconstruction. The data sets collected for solid-state NMR that lead to resonance assignments and structure determinations are quite different from those used in solution NMR. The objectives of this project are to develop a robust and efficient, end-to-end computational platform; a. To develop an automation platform for ssNMR-based protein research. b. To develop graphical user interfaces (GUIs) for the analysis of biomolecular ssNMR data. c. To produce web services and public resources for biomolecular ssNMR. The software and related educational materials will be freely disseminated by NMRFAM web services (www.nmrfam.wisc.edu), the NMRbox Project (www.nmrbox.org), and the SBGrid Consortium (www.sbgrid.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the 5-year period of NSF funding, we have been able to tackle the challenges of biomolecular solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) spectroscopy through the development of a robust and efficient, end-to-end computational platform. This is a particularly important area because ssNMR data enables to facilitate investigations of larger and less soluble proteins, such as nano/microcrystalline globular proteins, membrane proteins, and fibrils. The platform development was focused on developing analogous computational platforms to those developed for solution NMR that we had been developed. We have developed, tested, and deployed a comprehensive computational platform for interpretating multinuclear, multi-dimensional solid-state NMR data by integrating algorithms, visual tools, databases, web services, and video tutorials. The software and related educational materials are freely disseminated by POKY web services, the NMRbox Project, and the SBGrid Consortium.

 

In line with the scope of this NSF award, we have developed a new pulse sequence, automated peak picking, assignment and structure calculation and analysis programs for ssNMR. This has been integrated into the modern software suite, POKY (Lee et al., 2021), which has succeeded globally popular NMRFAM-SPARKY. 

 

We have collaborated with the Wi group at the National High-Magnetic Field Laboratory in developing efficient pulse sequences for long-range 15N-15N NMR correlations (Wi et al., 2024). It utilizes a homonuclear dipolar recoupling scheme, Adiabatic Linearly FREquency Swept reCOupling (AL FRESCO) to achieve remarkably low radiofrequency (RF) power demands, enabling efficient seconds-long mixing schemes regardless of the magic angle spinning (MAS) rate and nearly free from dipolar truncation effects. With this new pulse sequence, distance restraints essential for protein 3D structure calculation will be able to be obtained more robust and reliable without losing signals due to probe heat-up.

 

The new automated NMR peak picking program, iPick, has been developed and introduced (Rahimi et al., 2021). It provides a scripting tool and a graphical user interface (GUI), which allow the user to perform interactive and intuitive peak picking and validation. If used with a multi-core CPU, iPick reduces the processing time significantly by invoking parallel computing. Often clustered multiple peaks hamper this automation process. Therefore, we have developed and presented a new program REDEN (Residual Decomposition of NMR peaks) to visually assist the decomposition of clustered peaks in a chosen region (Rahimi et al., 2024). It performs multi-fitting simulated peaks with four lineshape fitting options. Combined use of iPick and REDEN is expected to provide ideal peak lists for automated assignment algorithms we also develop.

 

The new automated algorithm for ssNMR spectrum assignment, ssPINE, has been developed and introduced (Dwarasala et al., 2022). The ssPINE accepts the sequence of the protein plus peak lists from a variety of ssNMR experiments as inputs and offers automated backbone and sidechain assignments. Fourteen different NMR experiments are described and implemented in the Bayesian framework to achieve successful assignment automation, tested with more than 30,000 resonance chemical shifts. We have also developed a webserver to provide this algorithm to lower the barrier for ssNMR users. Additionally, semi-automatic assignment program called Versatile Assigner and the associated strategies have been developed to ensure assignment quality and fill the gap in the automation (Manthey et al., 2022). Versatile Assigner is capable of “linking predictions” from multiple residues in order to assign of sub-sequences. By finding two or more consecutive sequential predictions, the user can narrow down their position in the overall peptide sequence.

 

New structure analysis and determination tools have been developed. PISA-SPARKY has been developed and introduced as a plugin to NMRFAM-SPARKY, which later included in POKY (Weber et al., 2020). It performs PISA-wheel simulations, exhaustive fitting against experimental spectra, error analysis and dipolar and chemical shift wave plotting, that lead to provide topological restraints for structure determination and potentially provide highly sensitive probes that capture subtle signal transduction mechanisms that conventional structural techniques miss. Subsequently, we have developed a toolset for ssNMR-based 3D structure determination in the POKY suite (Rahimi et al., 2022). It comprises automatic restraint generation programs, easy-to-use programs for structure calculation and refinement like POKY Structure Builder and Analyzer.  

 

We believe we have been highly productive in these periods and pushing the limits of ssNMR-based protein structure research. These deliverables have been actively disseminated and supported through publications, conferences, workshops, Internet user groups, and YouTube channels. We plan to continue our development and expand to more complicated biological systems using our developed technologies such as IDPs, different nuclei and higher dimensional spectra so that we provide tools to tackle difficult problems that we have in the world today.
